repnme.cdata!:
Mongolia - Second Ulaanbaatar Services
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Ulaanbaatar
            Services Improvement Project for Mongolia were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the project
            was intended to provide improved water supply service to the
            urban poor. It is now clear that the government should have
            provided subsidies for this kind of project. However, the
            true nature of the project was not fully documented in the
            project appraisal document, or PAD, and hence the municipal
            government did not take any action to provide such
            operational subsidies. This issue should have been dealt
            with at appraisal, and the role of the government should
            have been more clearly defined upfront. Prior to project
            implementation, it is important to have clear guidelines on
            cost sharing and responsibilities of households. Where
            feasible, customers should contribute financially to
            investments to foster their ownership. It is important that
            the project owner educate users more proactively to inform
            them of their responsibilities to maintaining the system.
            One of the major design flaws of the pilot private
            connections in Dambadarjaa was the estimation of water
            consumption. The standards in the urban area are not
            applicable for the current situation of ger areas. It is
            important to establish and apply standards that are suitable
            for ger areas.

repnme.cdata!:
Mongolia - Second Ulaanbaatar Services
            Improvement Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Ulaanbaatar
            Services Improvement Project (USIP2) for Mongolia is to
            provide improved water supply to the urban poor in a
            sustainable manner. The closing date for project will be
            extended from December 31, 2011 until February 29, 2012. The
            project has benefited more than 350,000 residents of ger
            areas of Ulaanbaatar by improving access to safe water
            supply. More than 50 percent of water kiosks in ger areas
            are now connected to the water supply network and serve 300
            to 500 customers per day per kiosk. The project is expected
            to meet its development objectives of providing improved
            water supply to poor residents of ger areas. The extension
            is necessary to complete the feasibility study for the
            USIP3. The consultant service contract was signed in
            September 2011, with some delay in mobilization and
            assignment changes. The extension will allow the consultants
            to complete the feasibility studies and prepare detailed
            designs and bidding documents for the investments for the
            first few years. This will be the third extension of the
            project, and the total extension would be 20 months.

repnme.cdata!:
Mongolia - Second Ulaanbaatar Services
            Improvement Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Ulaanbaatar
            Services Improvement Project for Mongolia is to provide
            improved water supply to the urban poor in a sustainable
            manner. This restructuring paper is states (i) a
            reallocation of International Development Association (IDA)
            funds; and (ii) an extension of the closing date until
            December 31, 2011. The borrower requested the restructuring
            of the project through a letter from the Ministry of Finance
            (MOF), dated June 8, 2011. The project was approved on April
            29, 2004 and has made steady progress towards its project
            development objectives. As of April 2011, nearly all the
            original components had completed. The remaining three
            activities, namely the household water and sewerage
            connections in Dambadarjaa ger area, installation of a
            telemetry system in central source, and installation of
            control and mechanical valves in the water network, are
            expected to be finalized by the end of June 2011. The
            project has benefited more than 300,000 residents of ger
            areas of Ulaanbaatar by improving both access to water and
            quality of water supply. More than 50 percent of water
            kiosks in ger areas are now connected to the water supply
            network and serve 300 to 500 customers per day per kiosk.
            The project also contributed to improving the operating
            performance of the Water Supply and Sewerage Authority of
            Ulaanbaatar (USUG). The project has savings of SDR 978,000
            (about US$1.5 million) from works and goods the borrower has
            requested an extension of the closing date from June 30,
            2011 to December 31, 2011 with three months of grace period.
            The extension is necessary to complete the additional activities.

Mongolia - Second Ulaanbaatar

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Urban development - Poverty
            reduction and promoting growth for urbanization

abstracts.cdata!:
This report on poverty reduction and
            promoting growth for urbanization as an aspect of urban
            development in Tunisia claims the World Bank aims to respond
            to both aspects of the challenge posed by urbanization by
            firstly, helping governments prepare proactively for new
            urban growth and, secondly, supporting improved service
            delivery for urban poor. In view of these goals, the
            institution will provide support for urban development
            through five types of activities, namely, 1) management,
            financing and management of cities; 2) improving urban
            poverty and poor housing; 3) cities and economic growth; 4)
            planning, housing and urban land; and 5) urban and disaster
            management and climate change.
